title: Mum describes horrific moment daughter, 4, was sucked into hot tub mechanism
text:
Isabella was seriously injured in a hot tub The mother of a girl seriously injured when she was sucked into the filter of a hot tub has spoken for the first time about what happened. 
Nicola Floyd was relaxing in a jacuzzi with her daughter when Isabella, 4, became trapped from sitting on the filter vacuum.
Lorry driver, 93, given the perfect send off as he is driven to his funeral on back of HGV In her first interview, Nicola said: ‘Isabella never cried, but she just started screaming, ‘My tummy, my tummy.’
‘She’d been sucked in and wasn’t strong enough to push herself out. I tried with everything I had, pulling away, but I couldn’t free her either.’
The force was so strong that she could only be freed when a lifeguard came to switch off the power.
‘When I pulled her out, her intestine was in my hands,’ Nicola said.
 
Isabella, on a day out at the theme park Paulton’s Park, in Hampshire in December 2016 (Picture: PA) ‘As a mum, I feel guilty but I had no idea the filter was there. I’d never have put her at risk like that,’ she said.
‘My priority now is her recovery. I don’t want to let her down again.’
Man suffers psychiatric episode on tram before falling asleep then dying Thankfully, doctors were able to save her life and she is now recovering from severe injuries to her bowel and intestines after being put into an induced coma.
 
On March 3, Isabella woke for the first time, asking her mum to read her a story.
She has moved out of intensive care onto a children’s ward where she is doing better.
‘Nobody can say much right now. We’ve no idea what the lasting impact will be,’ Nicola said.
‘Her stomach is still open at the moment, so she’ll need surgery to close it up and then we’ll go from there. We’re taking things day by day, but at least it’s not hour by hour anymore.
Nicola’s daughter Isabella, aged three and a half years old, in April 2016 (Picture: PA Real Life) Originally from Waterlooville, Hampshire, Nicola moved to Bulgaria in 2007 7 after seeing an advert and being drawn in by the beauty of the country.
Government suffers second Brexit defeat in House of Lords She met her partner, plumber Hristo Hristov, eight years ago and they tried for a baby for three years before their ‘miracle’ daughter Isabella was born in June 2012.
‘Isabella is a happy, full-of-life little child. She’s absolutely everything to me,’ said call centre worker Nicola.
‘She’s like a little fish. She absolutely loves swimming. Her favourite Disney princess is Ariel.’
 
 
 
 
 
Nicola’s daughter Isabella, on a day out at the theme park Paulton’s Park, in Hampshire, in December 2016 (PA Real Life) Before the accident, they went swimming every week.
On February 25 it was too cold to go outside so they went to the Admiral Hotel instead in Zlatni Piasatzi along with Nicola’s mother Barbara Burchell, 49.
A spokesperson for the Admiral Hotel said they would help with investigations into what caused the accident.
‘We express our most sincere sympathy to the parents and relatives of the injured child and we would like to assure them, that we are ready to give them any kind of support for the medical treatment and the convalescence of the child,’ they said.
